headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: CNN Hero Who is Changing the Lives of Refugees Through Music; Gabby Thomas Talks Winning Gold at Paris Olympic Games. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: RON DAVIS ALVAREZ, CONDUCTOR
utterances.sentences: An orchestra is like a community. Different people, different voices, different melodies. Everybody has their own role,and they all connect to each other. The violins listen to the cellos, and the cellos hear trumpets. Imagine if the world worked more like an orchestra. We would have a better world for sure. I was born in Caracas, Venezuela. I fell in love with music from my first class when I was 10. I went to the university studying conducting there, and I was working around Venezuela and around the world to teach orchestras and programs, and that`s how I came to Sweden. I came in 2015, and there was arriving so many refugees and asylum seekers. They were like completely lost. Music changed my life. I knew that. I know that. So in this moment, I know one solution. OK, one, two, and three, and four. Three and four. Dream Orchestra is open for anyone who wants to learn an instrument, especially families who are arriving to Sweden. All down, can we try it? Down. We teach different instruments at the same time, and we have from the very small kids to adults, and it`s an orchestra where the main language is music. Kids, parents, youth, more than 20 languages and more than 25 nationalities, and kids who are born here, we all need to learn from each other. My life is Dream Orchestra. I feel thankful to have them in my life, that we can play music together and help each other. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Next in our CNN 10 Olympian series this week is Team USA track and field superstar Gabby Thomas. She`s not just quick on her feet, being oneof the fastest women in the world, winning three gold medals in Paris. She`s also locked into her studies and personal growth. She graduated from Harvard with a degree in neurobiology, then a master`s in public policy from the University of Texas. I asked her all about her incredible journey and all about her pug back home that she just can`t wait to see. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: So you finally got that gold, but not just at gold. How are you feeling right now?

utterances.speaker: GABBY THOMAS, USA ATHLETE
utterances.sentences: I feel like on top of the moon right now. I mean, this Olympics was a dream come true for me. I got to participate inevery event that I wanted to run in and we got the job done. So I`m ecstatic.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Not just participate. I mean, you blew the field away. I mean, were you expecting that?

utterances.speaker: THOMAS
utterances.sentences: You know, you can never really expect to do that, you know, at this level, at this level, because everyone is so talented and incredibleat what they do. But I do know I`ve been training for years for this moment. So I really take advantage of that.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Now, neurobiology degree from Harvard, master`s from UT in public health, and by the way, volunteer at a hospital. I mean, how powerful isthe human mind?

utterances.speaker: THOMAS
utterances.sentences: It really is powerful. And I learned that in college. I have a really strong foundation on that. And that was one of the reasons why Iwanted to pursue neurobiology as my major. And having that deep understanding of it, I think has really helped me in my track career as well, because I understand what it takes to get to this level. I understand the mindset. I understand all of those little things that make a big difference. And the mindset is a difference between, you know, being on the podium and not.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Incredible. Now, it`s true that your mom like has to watch the races alone. And did she do it this time?

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Because this would be one you wouldn`t want to miss.

utterances.speaker: THOMAS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness. My mom gets so nervous for these races. She`s more nervous than I am. So she does not like being around people. Shereally does not even like being in the stands because she gets so nervous. So she did actually do that for the four by four. She was in the comfort of family at the hospitality, but it makes her more comfortable to do it that way.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: And what was it like having fans in general around this time giving you all that hype?

utterances.speaker: THOMAS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness. It was amazing. I remember back in the fall, I was shooting a commercial with Toyota and they had all of my family kind ofin the shoot. And they were celebrating this moment and kind of manifesting this moment for me. And it was exactly like that. It`s like they had envisioned it and it came true in this moment. And it was incredible. I couldn`t imagine how amazing would it feel to share these special moments with them.

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: How badly do you miss your fur baby, your pug Rico back home?

utterances.speaker: THOMAS
utterances.sentences: I cannot wait to see Rico. I think that`s one of the first things I thought about when I finished. I was like, OK, I`ve done the job. Now Iget to go home and hang out with my puppy. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Today`s story getting a 10 out of 10 is for anyone who had confused robot taxi on their bingo card. That`s what some sleep deprived SanFrancisco residents say has been keeping them up at night for weeks. The racket that`s keeping them up is from honking driverless taxis that have been returning from picking up fares to a neighboring parking lot. They just seem to be getting confused. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: RANDOL WHITE, SAN FRANCISCO RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Then it happened again and again. And I started thinking, well, this is an issue.(END VIDEO CLIP)
